case_name: Sree Meenakshi Mills Ltd., Madurai v. Their Workmen

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 217 of 1956 is an appeal by special leave from the decision dated December 7, 1953, of the Labour Appellate Tribunal of India, Madras, in Misc. Case No. 111-C. 387 of 1953.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 217 of 1956. Appeal by special leave from the decision date December 7, 1953, of the Labour Appellate Tribunal of India, Madras, in Misc. Case No. 111-C. 387 of 1953.

facts.text: Three appeals arise out of two industrial disputes Nos. 24 and 26 of 1951 between the appellants and their workmen.

anchor.surface_text: The following Judgment of the Court was delivered by GAJENDRAGADKAR J. These three appeals arise out of two industrial disputes Nos. 24 and 26 of 1951 between the appellants and their workmen.

facts.text: Dispute No. 24 of 1951 arisen between the management and workers of the Sree Meenakshi Mills Ltd., Madurai.

anchor.surface_text: Dispute No. 24 of 1951 had arisen between the management and workers of the Sree Meenakshi Mills Ltd., Madurai, whereas dispute No. 26 of 1951, was between the management and workers of the Thiakesar Alai Manapparai.

facts.text: Dispute No. 26 of 1951 between the management and workers of the Thiakesar Alai Manapparai.

anchor.surface_text: Dispute No. 24 of 1951 had arisen between the management and workers of the Sree Meenakshi Mills Ltd., Madurai, whereas dispute No. 26 of 1951, was between the management and workers of the Thiakesar Alai Manapparai.

facts.text: Both disputes were in respect of bonus claimed by the workmen for the year 1950.

anchor.surface_text: Both the disputes were in respect of bonus claimed by the workmen for the year 1950- The workmen claimed bonus for the year 1950-51 on the allegation that the two mills companystituted one unit and had made profits during the relevant year.

facts.text: Workmen claimed bonus for 1950-51 alleging two mills constituted one unit and made profits.

anchor.surface_text: The workmen claimed bonus for the year 1950-51 on the allegation that the two mills companystituted one unit and had made profits during the relevant year. On the other hand, the appellants companytended that the two mills were two different units

facts.text: Appellants contended two mills were different units and there was trading loss, no bonus payable.

anchor.surface_text: On the other hand, the appellants companytended that the two mills were two different units and the claims for bonus made by the workmen against them should number be companysidered together. According to the appellants, during the relevant year there was a trading loss and as such numberbonus was payable to the workers.

facts.text: Industrial Tribunal rejected appellants' pleas, held two mills same unit, surplus Rs. 2,87,676, awarded three months bonus.

anchor.surface_text: The Industrial Tribunal rejected the pleas raised by the appellants and held that the two mills formed part of the same unit. It also came to the companyclusion that for the year in question there was a surplus of Rs. 2,87,676 against which the workmens claim for bonus was justified. That is why the tribunal awarded three months bonus to the workmen.

facts.text: Appellants preferred appeals Nos. 133 and 134 of 1952 to Labour Appellate Tribunal, Madras.

anchor.surface_text: Against this decision the appellants preferred two appeals Nos. 133 and 134 of 1952 to the Labour Appellate Tribunal of India at Madras.

facts.text: Workmen preferred appeal No. 168 of 1952 to Labour Appellate Tribunal claiming larger bonus.

anchor.surface_text: The workmen also preferred an appeal, No. 168 of 1952, and in this appeal they claimed a larger bonus than what had been awarded by the tribunal below.

facts.text: Labour Appellate Tribunal confirmed two mills same unit.

anchor.surface_text: The appellate tribunal companyfirmed the finding of the tribunal that the two mills formed part of the same unit.

facts.text: Labour Appellate Tribunal found net surplus Rs. 2,57,496 available for bonus.

anchor.surface_text: According to the appellate tribunal, the net surplus available for distribution as bonus came to Rs. 2,57,496.

facts.text: Labour Appellate Tribunal disallowed Rs. 4,43,927 of depreciation claim out of Rs. 8,43,927.

anchor.surface_text: In respect of an amount of Rs. 8,43,927 claimed by the appellants as depreciation on machinery and buildings the appellate tribunal companycurred with the industrial tribunal in holding that the claim only for a sum of Rs. 4,00,000 was admissible in other words, a claim for deducting the balance of Rs. 4,43,927 was disallowed.

facts.text: Labour Appellate Tribunal agreed provision for taxation Rs. 1,75,000 adequate.

anchor.surface_text: it may be pointed out at this stage that in determining the amount of net surplus available for distribution as bonus, the appellate tribunal agreed with the industrial tribunal that the provision for taxation made by the appellants to the extent of Rs. 1,75,000 was adequate.

facts.text: Appeals by appellants and respondents dismissed by Labour Appellate Tribunal.

anchor.surface_text: In the result, the appeals preferred by the appellants as well as the respondents failed and were dismissed by the appellate tribunal.

facts.text: Appellants preferred Civil Appeals Nos. 218 and 219 of 1956 to Supreme Court by special leave.

anchor.surface_text: Against the order dismissing their appeals, the appellants have preferred to this Court by special leave the present Civil Appeals Nos. 218 and 219 of 1956.

facts.text: Appellants filed review application Misc. Case No. III-C-387 of 1953 before Labour Appellate Tribunal.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants had also preferred an application for review before the Labour Appellate Tribunal, Misc. Case No. III-C- 387 of 1953  Review  on the ground that the order passed by the Labour Appellate Tribunal was patently erroneous inasmuch as there was a mistake apparent on the face of the record

facts.text: Labour Appellate Tribunal held no power of review and no mistake apparent on record.

anchor.surface_text: The appellate tribunal hold that it had numberpower of review and that,- even if it bad such a power, numbercase had been made out for the exercise of such power because there was numbermistake apparent on the face of the record which companyld number have been discovered whet  the order was made

facts.text: Appellants preferred Civil Appeal No. 217 of 1956 against review dismissal.

anchor.surface_text: Against this decision, the appellants have preferred to this Court by special leave the present Civil A peal No. 217 of 1956.

facts.text: Gross total profit Rs. 16,44,838 as per appellate tribunal summary.

anchor.surface_text: Total Rs. 16,44,838 Thus the gross total profit companyes to Rs. 16,44,838.

facts.text: Net surplus available for bonus Rs. 2,57,496 as calculated by appellate tribunal.

anchor.surface_text: Thus the net surplus available fordistribution as bonus companyes to Rs. 16,44,838 minusRs. 13,87,342. Rs. 2,57,496.

facts.text: Depreciation debited by appellants Rs. 8,43,927.

anchor.surface_text: Add depreciation debited by the companypany Rs.8,43,927

facts.text: Depreciation allowed Rs. 4,00,000.

anchor.surface_text: Depreciation allowed Rs.4,00,000

facts.text: Inspection of accounts allowed by Industrial Tribunal on workmen's application.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that, when the proceedings were pending before the industrial tribunal, an application was made by the workmen requesting the tribunal to direct the appellants to allow the workmen inspection of accounts. The Tribunal passed an order for inspection and inspection was allowed.

facts.text: Appellants failed to provide details of depreciation Rs. 8,44,000 on February 28, 1952 application.

anchor.surface_text: Thereupon an application was made on behalf of the workmen on February 28, 1952, for particulars relating to the amount of Rs. 8,44,000 claimed by the appellants by way of depreciation. The appellants promised to supply the information on March 8, 1952 but ultimately, on behalf of the appellants, it was stated to the tribunal that the appellants were number able to give the details called for.
Appeal by special leave from the decision dated December 7, 1953, of the Labour Appellate Tribunal of India, Madras,
Against the order dismissing their appeals, the appellants have preferred to this Court by special leave the present Civil Appeals Nos. 218 and 219 of 1956.
Against this decision, the appellants have preferred to this Court by special leave the present Civil A peal No. 217 of 1956.

This principle has been recognized by what is often described as the Full Bench formula as laid down in the matter of The -Mill Owners Association, Bombay v. The Rashtriya Mill Mazdoor Sangh, Bombay  1 . According to this formula, distributable surplus has to be ascertained after providing from the gross profits for  1  depreciation,  2  rehabilitation,  3  return at 6 on the paid-up capital,  4  return on the working capital at a lesser but reasonable rate, and  5  for an estimated amount in respect of the payment of income-tax.

concepts.interpretation: Distributable surplus ascertained after providing for depreciation, rehabilitation, return on capital, return on working capital, and estimated income-tax; applied to determine net surplus for bonus.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: s determined by the industrial tribunal should be taken to be gross profits that would be necessarily taxable under the Income-tax Act. Besides, it wo

concepts.unlisted_description: Formula for calculating available surplus for bonus distribution in industrial disputes

anchor.surface_text: Section 10 of the Income-tax Act provides for three kinds of allowances in respect of depreciation. Section 10  vi  deals with allowances in respect of depreciation of buildings, machinery, plant or furniture

concepts.interpretation: Provides for normal, initial, and additional depreciation allowances; tribunals not bound to allow initial and additional depreciation as prior charges in bonus calculations.
concepts.unlisted_description: Provisions on depreciation allowances (normal, initial, additional)

anchor.surface_text: the appellate tribunal can exercise its powers under O. 41, r. 21 as well as under s. 151 of the Code.

concepts.interpretation: Applies to proceedings before Labour Appellate Tribunal along with other CPC provisions.
Code of Civil Procedure including O.47 applies to Labour Appellate Tribunal proceedings, conferring power to review own orders.

anchor.surface_text: the appellate tribunal can exercise its powers under O. 41, r. 21 as well as under s. 151 of the Code.
Section 9 1  and s. 10 of the Industrial Disputes  Appellate Tribunal  Act, 1950, as well as the relevant rules and orders framed under the Act

concepts.interpretation: Along with CPC, governs proceedings before Labour Appellate Tribunal.

concepts.interpretation: Along with CPC, governs proceedings before Labour Appellate Tribunal.

anchor.surface_text: on the ground that the order passed by the Labour Appellate Tribunal was patently erroneous inasmuch as there was a mistake apparent on the face of the record

concepts.interpretation: No mistake apparent on record justifying review; argument on tax provision increase rejected as gross profits for bonus not same as taxable profits.
concepts.unlisted_label: Mistake Apparent on the Face of the Record
concepts.unlisted_description: Ground for review under CPC O.47

anchor.surface_text: only normal depreciation including multiple shift depreciation, but not initial or additional depreciation, should rank as prior charge

concepts.interpretation: Only normal depreciation allowed as prior charge under Full Bench formula, not initial or additional under Income-tax Act.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: has been drawn by Mr. Viswanatha Sastri is the decision of the Labour Appellate Tribunal in Bengal Chemical Pharmaceutical Works, Ltd. v. Their Workm

issues.text: whether, in determining the question as to whether net surplus is available for distribution by way of bonus or not, it is obligatory on the industrial tribunals to allow the whole of the depreciation admissible under the said provisions of the Income-tax Act.

anchor.surface_text: The question which arises for decision is whether, in determining the question as to whether net surplus is available for distribution by way of bonus or number, it is obligatory on the industrial tribunals to allow the whole of the depreciation admissible under the said provisions of the Income-tax Act.

issues.text: whether the appellate tribunal had jurisdiction to review its own decision under O. 47 of the Code of Civil Procedure.

anchor.surface_text: the appellate tribunal was in error in holding that it had numberjurisdiction to review its decision under 0. 47 of the Code of Civil Procedure.

issues.text: whether the appellants had made out a case for review on merits, specifically whether there was a mistake apparent on the face of the record regarding provision for income-tax due to disallowed depreciation.

anchor.surface_text: It has also been argued that on the merits it was wrong to have held that the appellants had failed to make out a case for the exercise of the said jurisdiction.

issues.text: whether the appellate tribunal erred in law in disallowing the appellants' claim for depreciation to the extent of Rs. 4,43,927 in calculating the net surplus for bonus.

anchor.surface_text: In appeals Nos. 218 and 219 of 1956, the main point which has been urged before us on behalf of the appellants is that the appellate tribunal erred in law in disallowing the appellants claim in respect of depreciation debited by the appellants to the extent of Rs. 4,43,927.

anchor.surface_text: In appeals Nos. 218 and 219 of 1956, the main point which has been urged before us on behalf of the appellants is that the appellate tribunal erred in law in disallowing the appellants claim in respect of depreciation debited by the appellants to the extent of Rs. 4,43,927.

arguments.court_reasoning: Only normal depreciation ranks as prior charge under Full Bench formula; initial and additional depreciation not obligatory per U.P. Electric Supply Full Bench precedent

arguments.claim: Default in supplying particulars does not justify drastic reduction in depreciation claim; audited balance sheet makes disallowance unreasonable
arguments.court_reasoning: Justified to comment on default but ultimate disallowance based on not bound to allow initial/additional depreciation

arguments.claim: Industrial tribunals must allow whole of depreciation admissible under Income-tax Act provisions in determining net surplus for bonus

anchor.surface_text: The question which arises for decision is whether, in determining the question as to whether net surplus is available for distribution by way of bonus or not, it is obligatory on the industrial tribunals to allow the whole of the depreciation

arguments.court_reasoning: Not obligatory; only normal depreciation as prior charge per Full Bench formula and social justice considerations differ from Income-tax Act

arguments.claim: Labour Appellate Tribunal has no power of review

anchor.surface_text: The appellate tribunal held that it had no power of review and that,- even if it had such a power, no case had been made out for the exercise of such power because there was no mistake apparent on the face of the record

arguments.court_reasoning: Code of Civil Procedure including O.47 applies to Labour Appellate Tribunal proceedings per Martin Burn precedent

arguments.court_reasoning: CPC applies to tribunal per ss.9(1),10 Industrial Disputes Appellate Tribunal Act and Martin Burn

arguments.claim: No mistake apparent on record justifying review; point not raised earlier, no new matter
arguments.court_reasoning: Technically force but court examines merits anyway since written statement filed

arguments.claim: Mistake apparent on record: disallowed depreciation adds to gross profits requiring higher income-tax provision (Rs.1,75,000 inadequate, should be Rs.4,75,582)
arguments.court_reasoning: Bonus gross profits not same as taxable profits; initial/additional depreciation exempt from tax under IT Act s.10

arguments.claim: Only normal depreciation (not initial or additional) ranks as prior charge in Full Bench formula for bonus

anchor.surface_text: only normal depreciation including multiple shift depreciation, but not initial or additional depreciation, should rank as prior charge

arguments.claim: Distributable surplus ascertained per Full Bench formula after prior charges including depreciation, rehabilitation, returns on capital, income-tax

anchor.surface_text: This principle has been recognized by what is often described as the Full Bench formula as laid down in the matter of The -Mill Owners Association, Bombay v. The Rashtriya Mill Mazdoor Sangh, Bombay 1 . According to this formula, distributable surplus has to be ascertained after providing from the gross profits for 1 depreciation, 2 rehabilitation, 3 return at 6

arguments.claim: Bonus claim justified only if living wages shortfall and profits partly due to workmen contribution after prior charges

anchor.surface_text: It has been held by this Court in Muir Mills Co. Ltd. v. Suti Mills Mazdoor Union, Kanpur 1 that the term bonus is applied to a cash payment made in addition to wages. It generally represents the cash incentive given conditionally on certain standards of attendance and efficiency being attained.

holdings.text: It is not obligatory on the industrial tribunals to allow the whole of the depreciation admissible under the provisions of the Income-tax Act in determining whether net surplus is available for distribution by way of bonus.

anchor.surface_text: The question which arises for decision is whether, in determining the question as to whether net surplus is available for distribution by way of bonus or not, it is obligatory on the industrial tribunals to allow the whole of the depreciation admissible under the said provisions of the Income-tax Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Full Bench formula governs bonus surplus; only normal depreciation ranks as prior charge, not initial or additional under IT Act, following U.P. Electric Supply Co. Full Bench to balance social justice for workmen.

holdings.text: The appellate tribunal did not err in law in disallowing the appellants' claim for depreciation to the extent of Rs. 4,43,927 as only normal depreciation is allowable as prior charge.

anchor.surface_text: In appeals Nos. 218 and 219 of 1956, the main point which has been urged before us on behalf of the appellants is that the appellate tribunal erred in law in disallowing the appellants claim in respect of depreciation debited by the appellants to the extent of Rs. 4,43,927.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Tribunals justified in limiting to Rs. 4,00,000 normal depreciation per Full Bench formula; appellants' failure to provide details noted but decision based on law, not just default.

holdings.text: The Labour Appellate Tribunal has jurisdiction to review its own decisions under O. 47 of the Code of Civil Procedure.
holdings.reasoning_summary: CPC applies to LAT proceedings per ss. 9(1) & 10 Industrial Disputes Appellate Tribunal Act and Martin Burn Ltd. precedent; O.47 included like O.41 r.21 and s.151.

holdings.text: The appellants failed to make out a case for review on merits as there was no mistake apparent on the face of the record regarding the provision for income-tax.

anchor.surface_text: It has also been argued that on the merits it was wrong to have held that the appellants had failed to make out a case for the exercise of the said jurisdiction.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Gross profits for bonus differ from taxable profits; disallowed initial/additional depreciation exempt from tax under IT Act s.10; no addition to tax provision needed.

precedents.cited_holding: Bonus is not bounty or deferred wages but share in surplus

The Rashtriya Mill Mazdoor Sangh, Bombay  1 . According to this formula, distributable surplus has to be ascertained after providing from the gross profits for

precedents.case_name: Mill Owners Association, Bombay v. Rashtriya Mill Mazdoor Sangh, Bombay
precedents.cited_proposition: Full Bench formula for ascertaining distributable surplus after prior charges like depreciation, rehabilitation, return on capital, working capital, income-tax

precedents.citation: U.P. Electric Supply Co. Ltd. v. Their Workmen

anchor.surface_text: This question has been decided by a Full Bench of the Labour Appellate Tribunal in U.P. Electric Supply Co. Ltd. v. Their Workmen  1 . It is true that the question of bonus had to be considered in this case in the light of the provisions of the U. P. Electricity  Supply  Act, 1948.

precedents.case_name: U.P. Electric Supply Co. Ltd. v. Their Workmen
precedents.cited_proposition: only normal depreciation ranks as prior charge in Full Bench formula, not initial or additional depreciation
precedents.cited_holding: Initial and additional depreciation are abnormal, for limited period, not fair as prior charges before surplus for bonus

precedents.citation: The U.P. Electric Supply Co. Ltd.

anchor.surface_text: On the whole, the reasons given by the appellate tribunal in the case of The U.P. Electric Supply Co. Ltd.  1  appear to us to be satisfactory and so we are not prepared to accept the appellants argument that the appellate tribunal in the present case has erred in law in not allowing the appellants claim for initial and additional depreciations.

precedents.case_name: U.P. Electric Supply Co. Ltd. v. Their Workmen
precedents.cited_proposition: reasons for disallowing initial and additional depreciation as prior charge

precedents.citation: Mills. Martin Burn Ltd. v. R. A. Banerjee  Civil Appeal No. 92 of 1957

anchor.surface_text: This Court has recently had occasion to consider the question about the applicability of the Code of Civil Procedure to the proceedings before the Labour Appellate Tribunal in Mills. Martin Burn Ltd. v. R. A. Banerjee  Civil Appeal No. 92 of 1957 . Section 9  1  and s. 10 of the Industrial Disputes  Appellate Tribunal  Act, 1950,

precedents.case_name: Martin Burn Ltd. v. R. A. Banerjee
precedents.cited_proposition: Code of Civil Procedure applies to proceedings before Labour Appellate Tribunal
precedents.cited_holding: CPC applies, including powers under O.41 r.21 and s.151

precedents.citation: Model Mills, etc. Textile Mills Nagpur v. Rashtriya Mill Mazdoor Sangh

anchor.surface_text: It would not be necessary to refer briefly to the decisions of industrial courts to which our attention has been drawn by the learned counsel for the appellants. In Model Mills, etc. Textile Mills Nagpur v. Rashtriya Mill Mazdoor Sangh  1 , the implications of the Full Bench formula for ascertainment of bonus have been explained.

precedents.case_name: Model Mills Textile Mills Nagpur v. Rashtriya Mill Mazdoor Sangh
precedents.cited_proposition: Full Bench formula equates rights of capital and labour; income-tax on trading profits deducted even if exempt due to past losses

precedents.citation: Mahalaxmi Wollen Mills Ltd. v. Their Work-Workmen

anchor.surface_text: The same view has been expressed by the appellate tribunal in Mahalaxmi Wollen Mills Ltd. v. Their Work-Workmen 1  In this case, it has been held that even if a concern is allowed exemption from the levy of incometax because of prior losses or unabsorbed depreciation, etc., that by itself is notground for preventing the concern from claiming the amount of income- tax it would have been liable to pay if the profits made in the relevant year alone had been taken into account.

precedents.case_name: Mahalaxmi Woollen Mills Ltd. v. Their Workmen
precedents.cited_proposition: deduct income-tax payable on relevant year's trading profits irrespective of actual payment due to prior losses

precedents.citation: Bennett Coleman and Company, Ltd. v. Their Workmen

anchor.surface_text: Similarly in Bennett Coleman and Company, Ltd. v. Their Workmen 2  the Labour Appellate Tribunal has held that unabsorbed depreciation and loss incurred during prior years are allowed under s. 24  2  of the Income-tax Act to be adjusted against the profits of a future year.

precedents.case_name: Bennett Coleman and Company Ltd. v. Their Workmen
precedents.cited_proposition: deduct income-tax on trading profits even if adjusted against prior losses/unabsorbed depreciation

precedents.citation: B. E. S. T. Workers Union v. Bombay Suburban Electric Supply Ltd.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Viswanatha Sastri has strongly relied on two labour decisions reported in B. E. S. T. Workers Union v. Bombay Suburban Electric Supply Ltd.  1 , and Greaves Cotton and Crompton Parkinson, Ltd. v. Its Workmen  2 . These two decisions no doubt support the appellants arguments before us but, for the reasons which we have already given, we must hold that these decisions are not sound or correct.

precedents.case_name: B.E.S.T. Workers Union v. Bombay Suburban Electric Supply Ltd.
precedents.cited_proposition: supports appellants' argument on provision for income-tax

precedents.citation: Greaves Cotton and Crompton Parkinson, Ltd. v. Its Workmen

precedents.case_name: Greaves Cotton and Crompton Parkinson Ltd. v. Its Workmen
precedents.cited_proposition: supports appellants' argument on provision for income-tax

precedents.citation: Bengal Chemical Pharmaceutical Works, Ltd. v. Their Workmen

anchor.surface_text: The last case to which our attention has been drawn by Mr. Viswanatha Sastri is the decision of the Labour Appellate Tribunal in Bengal Chemical Pharmaceutical Works, Ltd. v. Their Workmen  3 . This case decides that in providing for income-tax the tax payable by the concern on its income earned in the year for which bonus is claimed must be ascertained.

precedents.case_name: Bengal Chemical Pharmaceutical Works Ltd. v. Their Workmen
precedents.cited_proposition: income-tax provision based on tax payable on year's income, not actual paid (prior year)
